title: Rod Kafer
text:
Rodney B. Kafer (born 25 June 1971) is a retired <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player for the <a href="Brumbies">ACT Brumbies</a> and the Australian <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wallabies</a>. He is remembered by Brumbies fans for kicking a drop-goal in the final minute in a 2001 game against the Cats giving the Brumbies a one-point win. He now works for <a href="Fox%20Sports%20%28Australia%29">Fox Sports</a> as a rugby commentator and has a weekly segment on the show "Rugby HQ" called "Fox Field".
He attended <a href="Canberra%20Grammar%20School">Canberra Grammar School</a> in his youth. At the age of 15 he was diagnosed with <a href="type%201%20diabetes">type 1 diabetes</a>.
Kafer was the first player to have received winners medals from the major Southern and Northern Hemisphere rugby tournaments, the <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super 12</a> with the <a href="ACT%20Brumbies">ACT Brumbies</a> in 2001 and the <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> with the <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a> in 2002.
Kafer moved to the northern hemisphere in 2001 and spent two years playing for the Leicester Tigers before signing as player coach for <a href="Saracens%20F.C.">Saracens F.C.</a>. However, when <a href="Wayne%20Shelford">Wayne Shelford</a> was sacked as head coach, Kafer was appointed in his place and gave up playing.
In addition to his commentating commitments with <a href="Fox%20Sports%20%28Australia%29">Fox Sports</a> Rugby, Kafer previously owned a telecommunications company and sold it in 2014 and now works in the Australian Rugby Union in a high performance role.
